newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong Newspaper Headlines-May 2.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong Newspaper Headlines-May 2.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- MING PAO -- Beijing has decided to disband the Preparatory Committee before the handover, possibly at the end of the month after the general conference of the committee.
-- The Diaoyu Islands Action Committee is planning to go to the disputed islands again later this month.
-- SING TAO DAILY -- Washington has put Hong Kong back on its intellectual property rights "watch list", because copyright piracy had worsened in the territory over the past year.

-- ECONOMIC JOURNAL -- Sources said China's securities regulator has unofficially notified major investment banks that it would freeze approval for red chip shares seeking overseas listings for four months as it drafts guidelines for this area.

-- WEN WEI PO -- Director Zhou Nan of the Xinhua News Agency Hong Kong Branch said London had been short-sighted and under-estimated China, and the arguments between China and Britain were caused by British policies.
-- Chief Executive-designate Tung Chee-hwa said Hong Kong people were confident and were planning for the next century.
-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- Post-handover leader Tung Chee-hwa vowed to settle differences over planned changes to Hong Kong's civil rights laws.

-- Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission had appointed a well-connected mainland adviser on "China issues" to help it resolve increasing confusion over the regulation of mainland companies in the territory.
-- HONGKONG STANDARD -- Hong Kong is streamlining its Companies Ordinance, moving towards a simple Commonwealth model and doing away with complicated British style-legislation.
-- Hongkong Telecom is teaming up with the Beijing Telecoms Administration to offer an international frame relay service between Beijing and Hong Kong.
